com.tacticalenterprisesltd

Class Database

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.tacticalenterprisesltd.Database

  • public class Database
extends java.lang.Object
    The Database class performs all the necessary functions required to SELECT, UPDATE, INSERT, and DELETE records.
    This class supports the following database management systems:
    • MySql (default) v5.0 or higher
    • Oracle v12c or higher
    • SQL Server v2012 or higher

    The JED library of classes support DataTables on the server side for full CRUD (Create,Read,Update and Delete) operations, and are expected to be used in a Java environment using a servlet container such as Tomcat, or Glassfish.

    Setup:

    This library of classes are expected to be used in a JEE environment, and as such, it is assumed that you will be setting up an XML file for the Servlet Container that describes the necessary parameters required to obtain a database connection from a connection pool. The XML file I am referring to is generally named: context.xml. This file should reside in a folder named: META-INF. The context.xml file would look similar to this:

    <!-- New Context for MySQL Database Driver -->
    <!-- The following URL will point you to the correct syntax regarding CONTEXTs:
    http://jakarta.apache.org/tomcat/tomcat-5.5-doc/config/context.html -->
    <Context path="/JQuery" docBase="JQuery" debug="0"
    reloadable="true" crossContext="true">
    <!--Logger className="org.apache.catalina.logger.FileLogger"
    prefix="localhost_jquery_log." suffix=".txt"
    timestamp="true"/ -->
    <Valve className="org.apache.catalina.valves.AccessLogValve"
    prefix="localhost_jquery_log." suffix=".txt"
    pattern="common"/>
    <Resource name="jdbc/fcs_db" auth="Container" type="javax.sql.DataSource"
    username="webapp" password="secret" driverClassName="com.mysql.jdbc.Driver"
    url="jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/fcs_db?autoReconnect=true"
    maxActive="10" maxIdle="3" maxWait="10000"/>
    </Context>
    This context.xml example is for reference only. It is being used to access a MySQL database. This file was being used in a Servlet Container named Tomcat 7.0. You will need to change the parameters for your particular setup. Consult the documentation for your Servlet Container for more information. Your database drivers (contained in a jar file) for your particular system should reside in the WEB-INF\lib folder. In our case, we were using the mysql-connector-java-5.1.18.jar.

    Your basic directory structure for your application should look like this:

    [home_dir]
        |
        index.html
        |_ media
        |    |_ css
        |    |_ extensions
        |    |_ js
        |    |_ images
        |_ META-INF
        |        |_ context.xml
        |_WEB-INF
                |_ classes
                |_ lib
                    |_ jed-1.#.jar
                    |_ gson-2.2.4.jar
                    |_ log4j-1.2.8.jar
                    |_ mysql-connector-java-5.1.18.jar

    Usage Example:

    String dbName = "fcs_db";
    String[] tableNames = new String[]{"employees"};
    //Set the Primary Key field
    String pKey = "ID";
    Parameters params = new Parameters();
    //Acquire all the parameters passed to the Java Server Page
    ...
    Database db = new Database(dbName);
    Editor editor = new Editor(db, tableNames, pKey, params);
    Version:
    1.5.0
    Author:
    Alan Shiers

      • getConnection

        public java.sql.Connection getConnection(Database.RDBMS type,
                                java.lang.String classForName,
                                java.lang.String URL,
                                java.lang.String PORT,
                                java.lang.String UserName,
                                java.lang.String Password)
        This form of the getConnection method is made available for convenience and does NOT attempt to derive a Connection from a connection pool. Instead, it obtains a Connection by accessing a JDBC Driver directly so that you may connect to a different database other than the one that the servlet container has pooled.

        Example for connection to MySQL:

        getConnection(Database.RDBMS.MYSQL,"org.gjt.mm.mysql.Driver","localhost","3306","scott", "tiger")

        Example for connection to Oracle:

        getConnection(Database.RDBMS.ORACLE,"oracle.jdbc.OracleDriver","localhost","1521","scott","tiger")


        Example for connection to SQL SERVER:

        getConnection(Database.RDBMS.SQLSERVER,"com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerDriver","localhost","1433","scott","tiger")


        Don't forget to close the connection when you are done with it.
        Parameters:
        type -
        classForName -
        URL -
        PORT -
        UserName -
        Password -
        Returns:
        Connection

      • getConnection

        public java.sql.Connection getConnection()
        Obtain a Connection to perform a query. This method first creates a Context and performs a lookup on the system to obtain a DataSource object. From the DataSource, we return a Connection. To use this method, it is assumed you have created a context.xml file in the META-INF directory.

        It is this method that is called directly by the methods:

        executeSelect(), executeSelect(String strQuery),
        executeInsertUpdate(),executeDeletes(Query[] queries)
        Returns:
        Connection

      • executeFileSelect

        public java.io.InputStream executeFileSelect(java.lang.String pKey,
                                    int id,
                                    Field field)
                                      throws InsufficientDataException
        Use this method specifically for getting the binary data of a file contained in a database. The database field should be created of type TINYBLOB,BLOB,CLOB,NCLOB,MEDIUMBLOB,OR LONGBLOB. The type names may differ on other database systems, but as long as the field can hold large binary data, then you're good to go. The pKey and id values are used in a WHERE condition to obtain the specific record.
        Parameters:
        pKey - The name of the primary key field for the table in question
        id - The actual id value of the primary key field
        field - A Field object which should contain the names of the table and the field containing the binary file data
        Returns:
        An InputStream object
        Throws:
        InsufficientDataException

      • executeSelect

        public java.lang.String[][] executeSelect()
                                   throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        All data returned by this method will be obtained as a String regardless of each field type. If a field type that holds large amounts of binary data such as a BLOB, CLOB, NCLOB, LONGVARBINARY, etc. the return value will always be "***Binary Data Field***" regardless of whether the field is null or not.
        Returns:
        a 2D String[][] array
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

      • executeSelect

        public java.lang.String[][] executeSelect(java.lang.String strQuery)
                                   throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        This is a convenience method when a select query string is being supplied directly instead of using the Query object. All data returned by this method will be obtained as a String regardless of each field type. If a field type that holds large amounts of binary data such as a BLOB, CLOB, NCLOB, LONGVARBINARY, etc. the return value will always be "***Binary Data Field***" regardless of whether the field is null or not.
        Parameters:
        strQuery -
        Returns:
        A 2D String[][] array
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
